awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Exploring New Regimes of Physics to Constrain the Properties of Heating in the Solar Corona
awd_abstract_narration:
The main research objective of this five-year CAREER project is to investigate the physical mechanisms responsible for the heating of the solar atmosphere.  The project will explore challenging new regimes of physics, including: (1) non-equilibrium ionization due to the short timescales of plasma evolution during the heating events on the Sun; and, (2) substantial heat flux limiting and de-localization where the global plasma structure must be considered in the transport of energy through the solar atmosphere.  The proposed research program has two primary goals: (1) learn about the physics of the almost entirely unexplored regime of very high temperature, low density plasma in the solar corona; and, (2) use what is learned to find strong constraints on the properties of coronal heating.  The program of research presents the opportunity to study a new regime of thermal energy transport, in which the global structure of the plasma must be considered, and to determine how it affects the overall energy balance of the Sun's upper atmosphere.  This will be of value to other areas of space plasma physics.  By combining what is learned from the hot emission with what is already known from the warm emission, strong constraints will be placed on the properties of coronal heating.

The broader impacts of this CAREER project target students at all levels as well as educators.  The physics' topics on which this research is based will be incorporated into the solar astrophysics graduate course taught by the PI, from which a graduate student will be recruited specifically to work on this project.  The program also provides opportunities for undergraduate participation in research.  A major part of this project is a summer school program on key physical science concepts, taught within the context of the Sun, for rising juniors and seniors in the Houston Independent School District, which educates predominantly minority and socioeconomically disadvantaged students.  The mode of teaching will be through peer instruction and mentoring in small groups.  A high school teacher will assist the PI, and will develop lesson plans and other curriculum material based on the outcomes of the summer program for dissemination to other teachers, publication in educational journals, presentation at major conferences, and contribution to the Connexions website.  The research and EPO agenda of this CAREER project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of this research program was focused on exploring a new domain of very hot plasma (~10 MK) in the solar corona and what it can reveal about the properties of coronal heating. At the outset of the program the magnitude of the heating and the frequency of heating events were either entirely unknown or very poorly characterized. A major outcome of this work has been to finally dispell the notion that a steady (and grossly unphysical) heating mechanism is required to explain the presence of apparently steady coronal structures (structures that persist on timescales much longer than a cooling timescale). Deploying novel machine learning techniques has identified impulsive heating, intermittent on relatively short timescales (shorter than a cooling timescale), in the hot cores of active regions, whereas longer intervals between heating events have been found closer to their peripheries. The latter locations are believed to be source regions for the solar wind and so the findings from this research have also provided information concerning solar wind acceleration, allowing us to predict periodicities (e.g. in density and ionization state) in the outflowing plasma.

Another major outcome of this work has been a fuller understanding of the role that turbulence plays in the transport and dissipation of energy in the solar atmosphere. It has been shown that turbulence as a mechanism to convert magnetic energy into (ultimately) thermal energy can explain several key observed properties of plasma heating, such as the measured temperatures of individual ions. A paper published in Nature Astronomy discusses this finding. Turbulence can also strongly limit the flow of energy through the corona, in some cases accounting for the properties of coronal structures (e.g. magnetic loops) that do not conform to the classical scaling laws that relate their temperatures and densities; it provides a compelling explanation for the well-known (but difficult to understand and replicate in models) increase in the differential emission measure at coronal loop foot-points by physically justifying a spatial broadening of the local temperature gradient.

Several numerical tools that have been developed and/or significantly enhanced with respect to their capabilities, have been made publicly available to the scientific community via repositories such as GitHub. The work supported by this award has led to the PI being selected as the Lead Scientist for a NASA proposal to fly a next-generation space mission to make X-ray observations of the Sun.

With respect to broader impacts, the physics explored has been strongly multi-disciplinary. Contributions have been made to the study of interactions between magnetically active stars and their exoplanets using methods and tools developing during the course of this work, and this is expected to bear fruit concerning fundamental questions related to the atmospheric chemistry of exoplanets and, consequently, their habitability. Several large-scale efforts relevant to this are now underway, with the involvement of the PI. This project has also contributed to understanding phenomena observed in experimental laboratory plasma in the ultracold, strongly-coupled regime, which nonetheless exhibits physics relevant to the solar atmosphere, such as particular types of waves and the propagation of shocks. Finally, the Solar Academy, supported by this award, brought over 50 high school students to the Rice University campus and taught them how to use a broad range of resources to conduct research projects. Several Solar Academy participants made early decision and regular applications to Rice, and were enrolled as undergraduate students.
